Learning to read and write is:
  • Critical to a child's success in school and later in life
  • Most important during the Early Childhood period
Help parents understand the importance of their preschool-age children’s exposure to oral and written language.
Words and the ability to use language aren't acquired through passive listening.

Key Messages
  • Studies show that parents play a critical role in helping to support young children’s emerging literacy skills.
  • There are many ways to support young children’s literacy and learning through everyday activities and interactions.

audio.transcript: In a joint position statement of the International Reading Association and the National Association for the Education of Young Children, learning to read and write is said to be "critical to a child's success in school and later in life" and that "although reading and writing abilities continue to develop throughout the lifespan, the early childhood years - from birth through age eight -are the most important period for literacy development."

As trusted childhood advocates, early childhood professionals can help parents understand the importance of their preschool-age children's exposure to oral and written language, and how these experiences will impact their literacy and learning success as they continue to grow.

Words and the ability to use language aren't acquired through passive listening alone; rather, language is supported through and dependent upon verbal interactions and experiences with others. Parents and caregivers play a significant role in both the quantity and quality of language interactions and communication with their young children.

As you proceed through this topic, keep in mind the following Key Messages: Studies show that parents play a critical role in helping to support young children's emerging literacy skills, and that there are many ways to support young children's literacy and learning through everyday activities and interactions.
